unnormalised: New Delhi: India's decennial census, a massive undertaking, faced unprecedented delays due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The last complete census was conducted in 2011, putting India's population at 1.21 billion. The planned 2021 census was initially postponed and then further delayed, leading to data gaps and challenges in policy planning.
normalised: New Delhi: India's decennial census, a massive undertaking, faced unprecedented delays due to the C-O-V-I-D-nineteen pandemic. The last complete census was conducted in two thousand and eleven, putting India's population at one point two one billion. The planned two thousand and twenty one census was initially postponed and then further delayed, leading to data gaps and challenges in policy planning.

unnormalised: Provisional estimates, based on various surveys and projections, suggest India's population has now crossed 1.4 billion. Experts estimate that roughly 17.7% of the global population resides within India's borders. This makes accurate demographic data even more critical for resource allocation and infrastructure development.
normalised: Provisional estimates, based on various surveys and projections, suggest India's population has now crossed one point four billion. Experts estimate that roughly seventeen point seven percent of the global population resides within India's borders. This makes accurate demographic data even more critical for resource allocation and infrastructure development.

unnormalised: While the actual census data remains pending, projections indicate significant shifts in demographics. For instance, the under-15 population segment is estimated at 25%, reflecting a youthful demographic profile, while the 60+ age group makes up approx. 10.1% of the total population.
normalised: While the actual census data remains pending, projections indicate significant shifts in demographics. For instance, the under-fifteen population segment is estimated at twenty five percent, reflecting a youthful demographic profile, while the sixty plus age group makes up approximately ten point one percent of the total population.

unnormalised: The Registrar General of India anticipates the 2021 census data release sometime in late 2024 or early 2025. This information will be instrumental in refining existing policies and formulating new strategies to address evolving socio-economic needs across the country's 28 states and 8 Union territories.
normalised: The Registrar General of India anticipates the two thousand and twenty one census data release sometime in late two thousand and twenty four or early two thousand and twenty five. This information will be instrumental in refining existing policies and formulating new strategies to address evolving socio-economic needs across the country's twenty eight states and eight Union territories.
